To calculate the sum of squares from the series \( \frac{1}{2} \) downward multiplied repeatedly until reaching \(\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^{k}\) equal to \(\frac{1}{6622389}\), I need to express the fractions properly:
\[\begin{align*}
\frac{1}{\sqrt{\frac{1}{6622389}}} &= \sqrt{6622389},\\
\sqrt{6622389} &\approx 2571,\\
2571 \times 2 &= 5142,\\
5142 \times 2 &= 10284,\\
10284 \times 2 &= 20568,\\
20568 \times 2 &= 41136.\end{align*}\]
So adding them together results in approximately \(6622389\). However, rounding errors may occur because these calculations involve fraction operations whose precision depends on computational accuracy.
